SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. Bertha Lydia Hamilton

Present Address: 1270 8th Ave., Regina

Pioneer Address: 1270 8th Ave., Regina

Year you came to Saskatchewan: [1897]

(Drawing by Richard Grewen)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions information for later years is asked for, though in a few questions information for earlier years is also included.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that not everyone will be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your cooperation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Three close neighbors (2 miles)

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Noon. Never in evenings

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) People were always more welcome

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Cup of tea

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the places"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Bees for quilts for home use.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, other a month, etc.?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties?
